title: 105_s2545
content: The "Medicare HMO Protection Act of 1998" allows for the evaluation and alteration of termination decisions. The Social Security Act allows the Secretary to delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice plan if it poses a serious health risk to enrollees or reduces plan options significantly. The Secretary can delay the termination of a Medicare+Choice plan if it would significantly reduce plan options in the affected area or if the organization offers plans nearby without incurring substantial financial losses. The Secretary may conduct audits to make this determination. The Secretary may audit and inspect books or records of an organization to determine if a delay in terminating a Medicare+Choice plan is warranted to prevent substantial financial losses. The delay can be ended if an adequate provider network is established to maintain insurance coverage levels in the affected area. The Secretary may audit and inspect books or records of an organization to determine if a delay in terminating a Medicare+Choice plan is warranted to prevent substantial financial losses. An adequate provider network has been established to maintain insurance coverage levels in the affected area. If the Secretary delays termination, negotiations for a new contract under section 1857 can take place. The Medicare+Choice organization can negotiate for a new contract under section 1857 to continue coverage without adversely affecting beneficiaries. SEC. 3. Extension of initial Medicare+Choice contract period to 3 years. Amends Section 1857(c)(1) of the Social Security Act to require contracts to have a term of at least 3 years. Effective for contracts entered into after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. Notice of termination. Section 1857(d)(3) of the Social Security Act is amended to require Medicare organizations to provide written notice 120 days before contract termination, including information on alternative benefit options. The Social Security Act now requires Medicare organizations to give 120 days written notice before terminating a contract, including details on available Medicare+Choice plans, Medicare supplemental policies, costs, and local social service agency contact information for assistance. This amendment applies to termination notices provided after the enactment of this Act.
